RT @CllrRob: Which is why I'm talking to @Essex_CC ; landowners & @EnvAgency to see if a hybrid scheme, either side of the Coggeshall pinch‚Ä¶

@CllrRob @Essex_CC @EnvAgency Thank you, @CllrRob So important that we look at solutions that address all of the problems (naturally):  surface water run-off, Robins Brook AND Blackwater.  Look at the natural opportunities identified by @EnvAgency on a national project https://t.co/vgx7HUdajH

@EnvAgency has done excellent work to identify national natural flood management opportunities.  These work better for Coggeshall because tackle Robins Brook flooding & surface water & Blackwater.  Dam/Quarry only prevents SOME Blackwater flooding. #naturalinstead https://t.co/zvXBikgsq9

And @EnvAgency says "We will continue to be guided by 3 principles in choosing what we do: ‚Ä¢ Put people & wildlife first: our goal is to create a better place for them."  So plant trees, create attenuation ponds, don't quarry right up to medieval Coggeshall.  #sledgehammer

text: New rod license images celebrate Britain's coarse & trout species. Money from these has enabled @EnvAgency to open our rivers for coarse & migratory fish by funding projects like #DNAire https://t.co/d2NCwkYgNV https://t.co/0iGijn1mGl

Reading @EnvAgency 5 year plan. Nice words e.g. "We will use our voice, our evidence and our action to promote the environment and secure sustainable approaches" - so why not natural flood management on the river Blackwater?  Not 400 acre quarry; 300 m dam https://t.co/xKMxkIT1BO
